Topic One: The Enduring Good Deeds in the Book, the Sunnah, and the Athar (Narrations)
- The Enduring Good Deeds are those blessed words whose mention appeared in the texts of the Holy Book, and whose virtue and status were extensively mentioned in the texts of the pure Prophetic Sunnah. Many narrations about them were transmitted from the Imams of the Salaf (Predecessors) and the people of interpretation. Therefore, the discussion of this topic is in five sections:
- Section One: The Noble Verses and Honorable Hadiths mentioned regarding the Enduring Good Deeds.
- Section Two: The reason for the revelation of the verse of the Enduring Good Deeds.
- Section Three: The verses of the Enduring Good Deeds: explanation and clarification.
- Section Four: The meanings of the Enduring Good Deeds.
- Section Five: Adding the Hawqalah to the Enduring Good Deeds.

Section One: The Noble Verses and Honorable Hadiths mentioned regarding the Enduring Good Deeds
Many texts from the Book and the Sunnah mentioned the Enduring Good Deeds, and I will mention them through three branches:
Branch One: The Noble Verses mentioned regarding the Enduring Good Deeds:
The mention of the Enduring Good Deeds appeared in the Holy Quran in two places:
Place One: In Surah Al-Kahf: The Almighty said: [Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope (46)] (1).
Place Two: In Surah Maryam: The Almighty said: [And Allah increases those who were guided, in guidance, and the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for return (76)] (2).
Branch Two: The Honorable Prophetic Hadiths mentioned regarding the Enduring Good Deeds:
Many honorable Prophetic Hadiths appeared in the collections of the pure Sunnah mentioning the Enduring Good Deeds. I have chosen to rely on what is authentic among them, as the authentic suffices over the weak of these Hadiths:
a) The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Take your protection (Junnah). They said! O Messenger of Allah, is an enemy present? He said: "No, but your protection from the Fire. Say: 'Subhan Allah (Glory be to Allah), Al-Hamdu Lillah (Praise be to Allah), La ilaha illa Allah (There is no god but Allah), and Allahu Akbar (Allah is the Greatest)', for they come on the Day of Resurrection as saviors/leaders (Mujannibat) and followers (Mu'aqqibat), and they are the Enduring Good Deeds) (3).
Junnatukum: With Damma on Jim and Shadda on Nun: Meaning: What covers you and protects you.
Mujannibat: With Fatha on Nun, Meaning: Preceding in front of you.
Mu'aqqibat: With Kasra on the Qaf with Shadda, Meaning: Following you and coming from behind you (4).
Al-Hafiz Al-Manawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "They were called Mu'aqqibat because they returned time after time, and whoever did a deed and then returned to it has followed up ('Aqqaba)" (5).

b) The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, also said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar are from the Enduring Good Deeds" (1).
c) The Hadith of Al-Harith the freed slave of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Uthman sat one day and we sat with him, then the Muazzin came to him, so he called for water in a vessel I think it would contain a Mudd. He performed ablution then said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, performing ablution like this ablution of mine, then he said: "Whoever performs ablution like this ablution of mine then said: And prayed the Zuhr prayer, what was between it and Fajr is forgiven for him. Then prayed Asr, what was between it and the Zuhr prayer is forgiven for him. Then prayed Maghrib, what was between it and the Asr prayer is forgiven for him. Then prayed Isha, what was between it and the Maghrib prayer is forgiven for him. Then perhaps he spends the night turning over, then if he gets up and performs ablution and prays Fajr, what was between it and the Isha prayer is forgiven for him. And these are the good deeds (Hasanat) that remove the evil deeds." They said these are the good deeds, so what are the Enduring (Baqiyat), O Uthman? He said: "They are: La ilaha illa Allah, Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, Allahu Akbar, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah (There is no power and no strength except by Allah)" (2).
d) The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri -- may Allah be pleased with him -- from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Increase in the Enduring Good Deeds. It was said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: The Millah (Religion). It was said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: The Millah. It was said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "Takbir (saying Allahu Akbar), Tahlil (saying La ilaha illa Allah), Tasbih (saying Subhan Allah), Tahmid (saying Al-Hamdu Lillah), and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah" (3).
e) The Hadith of Al-Nu'man bin Bashir -- may Allah be pleased with him -- said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came out to us while we were in the mosque after the Isha prayer. He raised his sight to the sky then lowered it until we thought something had happened in the sky. Then he said: "Indeed, there will be after me leaders who lie and oppress. So whoever believes them in their lies, and assists them in their oppression, is not of me and I am not of him. And whoever does not believe them in their lies, and does not assist them in their oppression, he is of me and I am of him. Indeed, the blood of a Muslim is his expiation. Indeed, Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar, are the Enduring Good Deeds" (4).

f) The Hadith of Abdullah bin Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah has distributed your characters among you, just as He distributed your provisions among you. Indeed, Allah gives the world to whom He loves and whom He does not love, but He does not give Faith except to whom He loves. So whoever is stingy (Danna) with wealth to spend it, and fears the enemy to fight him, and dreads the night to endure it, let him increase in saying 'Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar'" (1).

Branch Three: The Narrations (Athar) mentioned regarding the Enduring Good Deeds
Among them:
a- The narration of Amara bin Sayyad, from Saeed bin Al-Musayyib, that he heard him say: regarding the Enduring Good Deeds: "It is the servant's saying: Allahu Akbar, Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah" (3).

Section Two: The reason for the revelation of the verse of the Enduring Good Deeds
Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari said: "And these verses from the Almighty's saying: [And recite, [O Muhammad], what has been revealed to you of the Book of your Lord...] to this place [Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope (46)] (1), it was mentioned that they were revealed regarding (Uyaynah bin Hisn and Al-Aqra' bin Habis)" (2). Then Ibn Jarir mentioned with his chain those who said that. He said: From Khabbab regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: [And do not send away those who call upon their Lord morning and afternoon, seeking His countenance. Not upon you is anything of their account and not upon them is anything of your account. So were you to send them away, you would be of the wrongdoers] (3). He said: "Al-Aqra' bin Habis Al-Tamimi and Uyaynah bin Hisn Al-Fazari came and found the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sitting with Bilal, Suhayb, Ammar, and Khabbab among people from the weak believers. When they saw them around him, they looked down upon them. They came to him and said: We would like you to make for us a session with you by which the Arabs would know our superiority. For the delegations of Arabs come to you, and we are ashamed that the Arabs see us with these slaves. So if we come to you, make them leave us. If we finish, then sit with them if you wish. He said: Yes. They said: Write a document for us against you regarding that. He said: So he called for the scroll and called Ali to write. He said: While we were sitting in a corner, Gabriel came down with this verse [And do not send away those who call upon their Lord morning and afternoon, seeking His countenance. Not upon you is anything of their account and not upon them is anything of your account. So were you to send them away, you would be of the wrongdoers] (4) then He said: [And thus We have tried some of them through others that they [the disbelievers] might say, "Is it these whom Allah has favored among us?" Is not Allah most knowing of those who are grateful?] (5)

Then He said [And when those come to you who believe in Our verses, say, "Peace be upon you." ... Your Lord has decreed upon Himself mercy: that any of you who does wrong out of ignorance and then repents after that and corrects himself - indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful] (1). So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, threw the scroll from his hand, then called us, so we came to him while he was saying: [Peace be upon you... Your Lord has decreed upon Himself mercy: that any of you who does wrong out of ignorance and then repents after that and corrects himself - indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful]. So we used to sit with him, and if he wanted to stand up, he stood and left us. So Allah Almighty revealed: [And keep yourself patient [by being] with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, seeking His countenance. And let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring adornments of the worldly life, and do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his desire and whose affair is ever [in] neglect]. He said: "So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to sit with us afterwards. If he reached the hour in which he stands up, we stood up and left him until he stands" (2).
Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said: "This is a Gharib (strange) Hadith, for this verse is Makki and Al-Aqra' bin Habis and Uyaynah only embraced Islam a long time after the Hijra" (3).
Sheikh Ahmad Shakir said after citing the aforementioned statement of Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir: This is the truth, Allah willing (4).
Abu Sa'id Al-Mula'i said: ".. But scholars agreed that this Surah is Makki, and the coming of Uyaynah bin Hisn and Al-Aqra' bin Habis and those whose hearts are to be reconciled to the Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and their addressing him was in Medina, this is in which there is no doubt. So the apparent meaning, and Allah knows best, is that these verses were revealed concerning the great ones of the polytheists from the people of Mecca who criticized the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, for the poor believers sticking to him like Suhayb and Bilal, may Allah be pleased with them, and they said to him: Drive these away from you until we come to you. Not concerning Uyaynah and Al-Aqra'. Or these verses are Madani. The first is closer and more correct due to their agreement on the Surah being Makki.." (5).

Section Three: The two verses of the Enduring Good Deeds: explanation and clarification
The Holy Quran is a sea with no shore and no bottom. Through these two noble verses, we try to review the sayings of the commentators and what the two verses of the Enduring Good Deeds contained of subtleties and meanings that indicate most greatly the greatness of this Quran, its miraculous nature, and its conciseness through three branches:
Branch One: On the interpretation of the Almighty's saying: [Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope (46)] (1).
a- Interpretation:
- The Quranic scholar Muhammad Al-Amin Al-Shanqiti - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: "The intent of the noble verse is to alert people to righteous deeds so they are not distracted by the adornment of the worldly life of wealth and children from what benefits them in the Hereafter with Allah of the enduring righteous deeds" (2).
- Ibn Ashur - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said regarding the Almighty's saying: [Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope (46)] (3). He said: "An interjection intended for admonition and lesson for the believers that the blessing the polytheists are in of wealth and children is only the adornment of the worldly life which you knew is transient..." (4).
- Al-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him, said regarding the Almighty's saying: [Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope (46)] (5): "This is a refutation of the leaders who used to boast of wealth, riches, and sons. So He, Glory be to Him, informed them that this is what one adorns himself with in the world, not what benefits in the Hereafter..." (6).

- Ibn Ashur, may Allah have mercy on him, said regarding His saying: [Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope (46)] (1): "Two adjectives modifying an omitted noun, meaning the enduring righteous deeds which have no cessation, meaning there is no cessation to their good which is their eternal reward. So they are better than the adornment of the worldly life which is not enduring.." (2).
Al-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him, said regarding the Almighty's saying: [better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope]: "Meaning better than this adornment of wealth and children in reward and more in return and benefit for their people." And better for hope "meaning better in hope: meaning that these righteous deeds, for their people, regarding hope are better than what the people of wealth and children hope for, because they attain by them in the Hereafter better than what these rich people hoped for in the world..." (3).
Ibn Ashur, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And the meaning of (and better for hope) is that the hope of the one hoping in wealth and children is only hoping for the occurrence of a matter doubtful in its occurrence and limited to its duration. As for the one hoping for the reward of righteous deeds, he is hoping for the occurrence of a matter promised by the Truthful Promiser.." (4).
b- Quranic Subtleties in the Verse:
Subtlety One: Ibn Ashur said: "The requirement of the apparent in the order of the two descriptions was to present the Righteous over the Enduring, because even though they are two descriptions for an omitted noun, the more known of them in describing that omitted [noun] is the Righteous, because it has become common to say the Righteous Deeds and not say the Enduring Deeds.. But the requirement of the apparent was opposed here, so the Enduring was presented to alert that what was mentioned before it was only separated because it is not enduring, which is wealth and children, as in His saying Almighty: [and the worldly life is not, compared to the Hereafter, except [brief] enjoyment] (5). So this presentation was fulfilling the right of conciseness by dispensing with an omitted speech whose estimation is that that is transient or what is not enduring, and the Enduring of the Righteous [deeds] are better than it.." (6).

Subtlety Two: Abu Hayyan Al-Andalusi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: ".. When He mentioned the destination of what is in the worldly life to annihilation, this particular [case] of wealth and children being adornment was included in it... And everything that is adornment of the worldly life is quick to expire, so wealth and children are quick to expire. And by the axiom of reason, what is like that, it is ugly for the rational person to boast of it or rejoice because of it" (1).
Subtlety Three: Imam Al-Qurtubi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Wealth and children are but adornment of the worldly life because in wealth is beauty and benefit, and in children is strength and defense, so they became the adornment of the world.." (2).
Ibn Ashur, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And presenting wealth over children in the mention is because it is quicker to come to people's minds, because the young and old, the youth and the sheikh desire it, and whoever has children, what has sufficed him..." (3).
Al-Qasimi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Presenting wealth over children due to its deep rootedness in what is linked to it of adornment and supply, and because the need for it is more touching, and because it is adornment without them unlike the reverse" (4).
Subtlety Four: Al-Qasimi said in Mahasin Al-Ta'wil: "Singularizing adornment (Zinah) even though it is attributed to two things, because it is originally a verbal noun (Masdar). It was applied to the object hyperbolically. As if it is the adornment itself. And adding it to life is for specification; because its adornment is specific to it" (5).
Al-Qurtubi said: "(Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life) And it is permissible [to say] 'Zinata' (two adornments) and it is the predicate of the subject in dual and singular form." (6)

Subtlety Five: Al-Qasimi said: "Bringing out the endurance of deeds and their righteousness in the manner of attributes that are taken for granted, even though their right is to be intended for benefit, especially in countering the affirmation of annihilation for what opposes them of wealth and children in the manner of [Whatever you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting] (1) to signal that their endurance is an established matter with no need for its explanation. Rather, the term 'Enduring' (Al-Baqiyat) is a name for it not a description, and for that reason the described noun was not mentioned. What needed to be addressed was its goodness" (2).
Subtlety Six: Al-Qasimi said: "Repeating (Better - Khayr) to signal the difference in the two aspects of goodness and exaggeration" (3).
Branch Two: On the interpretation of the Almighty's saying: [And Allah increases those who were guided, in guidance, and the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for return] (4).
a- Interpretation:
Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: When Allah Almighty mentioned providing the one who is in error in what he is in and increasing him in what he is upon, He informed of increasing the guided ones in guidance as the Almighty said: [And whenever a surah is revealed, there are among them those who say, "Which of you has this increased in faith?" As for those who believed, it has increased them in faith, while they are rejoicing (124) But as for those in whose hearts is disease, it has [only] increased them in abomination upon their abomination, and they died while they were disbelievers (125)] (5) (6).

Ibn Ashur, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And the Enduring Good Deeds are two adjectives for an omitted noun known from the context, meaning deeds enduring in their bliss and good. And the righteous deeds for their owners are better with Allah than the blessing of escaping punishment.." (1).
Ibn Kathir said: "Better to your Lord for reward: meaning recompense". "And better for return (Maradda): meaning outcome and return for its owner" (2).
b- Subtleties:
Al-Qasimi said: "Repeating the predicate is for more care in explaining it" (3).
Branch Three: On the disagreement of the commentators regarding the Enduring Good Deeds:
The people of interpretation differed in explaining the Enduring Good Deeds into four schools:
First School: That they are the blessed words "Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, Allahu Akbar, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah..".
This was narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, via a group of Companions like Abu Huraira, Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, Uthman bin Affan, Ibn Abbas, and Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them all.
And it was narrated from a group of the Followers like Saeed bin Jubayr, Ata bin Abi Rabah, and Saeed bin Al-Musayyib. And to this went Ikrimah, Mujahid, Al-Hasan, and Qatada from the Imams of Tafsir. It is the school of the masses of scholars of Tafsir (4).
The proponents of this view used as evidence the honorable Prophetic Hadiths which we cited in the first requirement.
Second School: That they are the five prayers.
This school was narrated from Ibn Abbas in a narration, Amr bin Sharhabil, Abu Maysarah, Saeed bin Jubayr in a narration from him, Masruq, and Ibrahim (5).

Third School: That they are righteous deeds absolutely.
This was narrated from Ibn Abbas as well, Abdul Rahman bin Zaid bin Aslam, and Ali bin Abi Talha. Qatada went to this, and a group of commentators preferred it, taking the generality of the wording (1).
Fourth School: That they are good speech:
This school was also reported from Ibn Abbas (2):
- Ibn Atiyyah Al-Andalusi said: "And Ibn Abbas saying all the opinions is evidence of him speaking of generality" (3).
Discussion and Preference:
From the previous sayings of the Imams of Tafsir and people of interpretation, the first opinion seems most correct to us for the following considerations:
1 - That it has been reported from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, interpreting the Enduring Good Deeds as Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar, as in the previous Hadiths from Abu Huraira, Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, and Abdullah bin Masoud, may Allah Almighty be pleased with them all. These Hadiths are authentic so they were the first reference in interpreting the Enduring Good Deeds.
2 - What is established from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, of interpreting the Enduring Good Deeds as Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, Allahu Akbar, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah. This is authentic from Uthman, Ibn Umar, and Ibn Abbas in the most authentic paths narrated from him.
3 - What was reported of narrations from a group of Followers like Saeed bin Al-Musayyib, Saeed bin Jubayr, and Ata bin Abi Rabah.
4 - That this opinion is the school of the majority of commentators.

Section Four: The meanings of the Enduring Good Deeds
The Enduring Good Deeds have great meanings mentioned by scholars in books of creeds and Tafsir, and mentioned by linguists in their dictionaries. They are also in books of strange narrations. So we restrict ourselves to mentioning a part of them in the following five branches:
Branch One: On the meaning of Tasbih:
Tasbih in language is: Tanzih (Exaltation/Purification) (1). The root of Nazh is: Distance. And Tanzih of Allah: Distancing Him from what is not permissible upon Him of imperfections (2).
And Subhan Allah: A proper noun for the meaning of innocence and exaltation (3).
And the meaning: Exalting Allah from [having] a female companion and child... And it is accusative as a verbal noun (Masdar), meaning I declare Allah innocent of evil an innocence (4). And Sabbaha Allah means Exalted Him and Sanctified Him (5).
- Ibn Al-Jazari said: "And the origin of Tasbih: Exaltation, Sanctification, and Clearing from imperfections... And it was said its meaning: Hastening to Him and agility in His obedience. And it was said its meaning: Speed to this word. Tasbih may be applied to other types of Dhikr metaphorically, like Tahmid and Tamjid and others. And it may be applied to voluntary prayer and Supererogatory (Nafila)" (6).

Section Five: Adding the Hawqalah to the Enduring Good Deeds
Hawqalah is "La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah". Its addition to the Enduring Good Deeds appeared in several Hadiths raised to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, narrated via Uthman, Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, and Ibn Masoud, may Allah be pleased with them all.
- From the Companions, Uthman bin Affan, Ibn Umar, and Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them - went to adding Hawqalah to the Enduring Good Deeds.
- And from the Followers, Saeed bin Al-Musayyib and Ata bin Abi Rabah, and Ibn Wahb said it (1).
Here are some Hadiths and narrations mentioned in the following two branches:
Branch One: The Hadiths narrated regarding adding Hawqalah to the Enduring Good Deeds:
a) The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Increase in the Enduring Good Deeds. It was said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Takbir, Tahlil, Tasbih, Tahmid, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah" (2).
b) The Hadith of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, for he was asked about the Enduring [deeds]? He said: They are "La ilaha illa Allah, Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, Allahu Akbar, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah" (3).
c) The Hadith of Abu Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I met Abraham on the night I was taken on the Night Journey, so he said: O Muhammad, convey my Salam to your Ummah and inform them that Paradise has good soil, sweet water, and that it is flat plains (Qi'an), and that its plants are Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar" (4). And Al-Tabarani added in Al-Saghir and Al-Awsat "La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah" (5).

Section Two: The Enduring Good Deeds, their secrets and status
The Enduring Good Deeds have a great status among other remembrances (Adhkar), and they have wondrous secrets that indicate their noble station and the secret of their great virtue. Despite their brevity, they have contained many meanings. I will write about their status and secrets in two requirements:

Requirement Two: On the status of the Enduring Good Deeds.

text:
Requirement One: On explaining the secret of the virtue of the Enduring Good Deeds
Sheikh Izz al-Din bin Abd al-Salam - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned in a famous treatise of his on Creed in which he answered some people of his time, written to him as a test, mentioned by Imam Taj al-Din al-Subki in full in Tabaqat al-Shafi'iyyah al-Kubra. He mentioned that Allah's ninety-nine Beautiful Names with which He named Himself in His Book and the Sunnah of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, are included in four words, which are the Enduring Good Deeds.
- The First Word: Saying Subhan Allah. Its meaning in the speech of the Arabs is exaltation and negation. It includes negating imperfection and defect from the Essence of Allah and His Attributes. So whatever of His names is a negation falls under this word, like Al-Quddus (The Holy) who is Pure from every defect, and Al-Salam (The Peace) who is safe from every bane.
- The Second Word: Saying Al-Hamdu Lillah. It includes affirming the types of perfection for His Essence and Attributes. So whatever of His names implies affirmation like Al-Alim (The Knowing), Al-Qadir (The Capable), Al-Sami' (The Hearing), and Al-Basir (The Seeing) falls under the second word. So we negated by our saying Subhan Allah every defect we reasoned and every imperfection we understood, and we affirmed by Hamd every perfection we knew and every majesty we perceived. And beyond what we negated and affirmed is a great matter that was absent from us and we were ignorant of, so we realized it from the aspect of generality by our saying Allahu Akbar, and it is:
- The Third Word: Meaning that He is more majestic than what we negated and affirmed, and that is the meaning of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "I cannot enumerate praise upon You, You are as You praised Yourself". So whatever of His names implies praise above what we knew and realized like Al-A'la (The Most High) and Al-Muta'ali (The Exalted) falls under our saying Allahu Akbar. If there existed of this nature, we negated that there be in existence one who resembles Him or equals Him, so we realized that by our saying "La ilaha illa Allah", and it is:
- The Fourth Word: For Divinity returns to entitlement to servitude, and no one deserves servitude except one who is described with all that we mentioned. So whatever of His names implies the whole in general like Al-Wahid (The One), Al-Ahad (The Unique), and Dhu Al-Jalal wa Al-Ikram (Possessor of Majesty and Honor) falls under our saying La ilaha illa Allah. He only deserved servitude because the descriptions of Majesty and attributes of Perfection became obligatory for Him, which describers cannot describe nor counters count.." (1).
From the previous, the secret of the distinction of these words over others, and the noble station they occupied over other types of Dhikr becomes clear to us. Imam Al-Hafiz Al-Manawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "These four words are the best speech because they imply exalting Him Almighty from all that is impossible for Him, and describing Him with all descriptions of perfection obligatory for Him, and His uniqueness due to His Oneness, and His specificity with His Greatness and Pre-eternity understood from His being Greater (Akbariyyah)" (2).

Requirement Two: On the status of the Enduring Good Deeds
Due to the greatness of the status of the Enduring Good Deeds, what indicates this great position and high rank has been reported in the purified Prophetic Sunnah through the following:
1 - The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made it suffice for the Holy Quran for the one who does not know it well.
Due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Abi Awfa who said: A Bedouin said: O Messenger of Allah, I have tried the Quran but I could not [learn] it, so teach me something that suffices for the Quran. He said: Say: "Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar". He said it and held it with his finger. Then he said: O Messenger of Allah, this is for my Lord, so what is for me? He said: Say: Allahumma Ighfir li Warhamni Wa 'Afini Warzuqni (O Allah forgive me, have mercy on me, grant me well-being, and provide for me), and I think he said: Wahdini (and guide me). The Bedouin went away. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The Bedouin went having filled his hands with good" (1). Al-Bayhaqi added: Wa La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah (2).
2 - That they stand in place of the great mother acts of worship like Jihad in the path of Allah, spending, and night prayer - whatever of it was voluntary.
Due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Indeed, Allah has distributed your characters among you just as He distributed your provisions among you. And indeed, Allah gives wealth to whom He loves and whom He does not love, but He does not give Faith except to whom He loves. So if Allah loves a servant, He gives him Faith. So whoever is stingy with wealth to spend it, and fears the enemy to fight him, and the night to endure it, let him increase in saying La ilaha illa Allah, Allahu Akbar, Al-Hamdu Lillah, and Subhan Allah" (3).
3 - That their place is around the Throne, reminding of their owner:
In the Hadith of Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, among what you mention of the Majesty of Allah, Tasbih, Tahlil, and Tahmid, curve around the Throne, having a buzzing sound like the buzzing of bees, reminding of their owner. Does not one of you love to have - or continue to have - someone who reminds of him" (4).

4 - That it is the gatherer of Good: Since it gathers for its owner goodness in his world and Hereafter.
- It was reported in the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, said: A Bedouin came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: Teach me words I can say. He said: "Say: La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, Allahu Akbar kabira, wa Al-Hamdu Lillahi kathira, wa Subhan Allahi Rabbi Al-Alamin, wa La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah Al-Aziz Al-Hakim" He said: These are for my Lord, so what is for me? He said: "Say: Allahumma Ighfir li Warhamni Wahdini Warzuqni", and in a narration "Wa 'Afini" (1). And in a narration he said: "For these gather for you your world and your Hereafter" (2).
- And in the Hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: A Bedouin man came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah: Teach me good. He said: "Say: Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar", then he returned. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw him, he smiled and said: "The miserable one thought." He said: O Messenger of Allah (Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar) this is all for Allah, so what is for me? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: If you say "Subhan Allah", Allah says: You have spoken the truth. If you say: "Al-Hamdu Lillah", Allah says: You have spoken the truth. If you say: "La ilaha illa Allah", Allah says: You have spoken the truth. If you say: "Allahu Akbar", Allah says: You have spoken the truth. So you say: Allahumma Ighfir li (O Allah forgive me), Allah says: I have done. So you say: Allahumma Irhamni (O Allah have mercy on me), Allah says: I have done. And you say: Allahumma Urzuqni (O Allah provide for me), Allah says: I have done. He said: So the Bedouin tied seven on his hands (3).
5 - That Allah Mighty and Majestic chose them from among all speech for their status and great virtue:
That was authenticated from the Hadith of Abu Huraira and Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with them, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah chose four from speech: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar. So whoever says: Subhan Allah; twenty good deeds are written for him, and twenty bad deeds are removed from him. And whoever says: Allahu Akbar, the like of that. And whoever says: La ilaha illa Allah, the like of that. And whoever says: Al-Hamdu Lillahi Rabbi Al-Alamin, from his own self, thirty good deeds are written for him, and thirty bad deeds are removed from him" (4).

Requirement One: On explaining the virtue of the Enduring Good Deeds generally
Many Hadiths were narrated regarding the virtue of the Enduring Good Deeds generally explaining their merit. I mention a part of what is authentic regarding them as follows:
1 - That they are the most beloved speech to Allah Almighty:
Due to the Hadith of Samurah bin Jundub, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The most beloved speech to Allah is four: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar; it does not harm you with which of them you started" (1).
2 - That they are the best (Atyab) of speech:
As in the Hadith of Samurah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "... Four are from the best of speech and they are from the Quran, it does not harm you with which of them you started: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar.." (2).
3 - That they are the most excellent (Afdal) speech:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "The most excellent speech is four: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar" (3).
4 - That they are more beloved than what the sun rose upon:
In the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "That I say: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar; is more beloved to me than what the sun rose upon" (4).
5 - That they are the best (Khayr) of speech:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "The best of speech is four, it does not harm you with which of them you started: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar" (5).

6 - That they are the plants of Paradise:
Several confirmed Hadiths from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, were reported regarding that as follows:
a. The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by him while he was planting a plant, so he said: "O Abu Huraira, what are you planting? I said: A plant. He said: "Shall I not guide you to a plant better than this? Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar. For each one, a tree will be planted for you in Paradise" (1).
b. The Hadith of Ibn Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I met Abraham on the night I was taken on the Night Journey, so he said: O Muhammad, convey my Salam to your Ummah, and inform them that Paradise has good soil, sweet water, and that it is flat plains, and that its plants are Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar" (2). And in a narration "And La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah" (3).
c. The Hadith of Salman, may Allah be pleased with him, said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saying: "Indeed, in Paradise are flat plains, so increase in its plants. They said: O Messenger of Allah, and what are its plants? He said: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar" (4).
d. The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever says: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar, a tree will be planted for him in Paradise for each one of them" (5).

7 - The greatness of its reward especially for one unable to perform worship:
It was confirmed in the Hadith of Umm Hani, may Allah be pleased with her, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by me one day, so I said: O Messenger, I have become old and weak - or as she said - so command me with a deed I can do while sitting. He said: "Glorify Allah (Sabbihi) a hundred times; for it equates for you freeing a hundred slaves from the offspring of Ishmael. And praise Allah (Ahmudi) a hundred times; for it equates for you a hundred saddled and bridled horses you carry upon in the path of Allah. And magnify Allah (Kabbiri) a hundred times; for it equates for you a hundred garlanded and accepted camels. And declare Allah's Oneness (Hallili) a hundred times. Ibn Khalaf said: I think he said: It fills what is between the heaven and the earth, and no deed is raised for anyone on that day unless he brings the like of what you brought" (1). And in a narration: "And declare Allah's Oneness a hundred times, it leaves no sin and no deed precedes it" (2).
8 - That they weigh heavy in the Balance on the Day of Resurrection and fill what is between the heaven and the earth:
- Due to the Hadith of Abu Salma - the shepherd of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saying: "Bakhin Bakhin (Excellent! Excellent!) for five, how heavy they are in the Balance: La ilaha illa Allah, Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, Allahu Akbar, and the righteous child who dies for a Muslim man and he seeks reward for him" (3).
- And it was confirmed in the Hadith of Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Purity is half of Faith, and Al-Hamdu Lillah fills the Balance, and Subhan Allah and Al-Hamdu Lillah fill what is between the heaven and the earth, and Prayer is light, and Charity is proof, and Patience is illumination, and the Quran is an argument for you or against you. Every person goes out morning, so he sells himself, either freeing it or destroying it" (4).

9 - That they are a protection (Junnah) on the Day of Resurrection coming from in front of their owner and from behind him as protection from the Fire.
Due to what is in the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Take your protection" They said: O Messenger of Allah: Is an enemy present? He said: "No, but your protection from the Fire. Say: Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar; for they come on the Day of Resurrection as saviors/leaders (Mujannibat) and followers (Mu'aqqibat), and they are the Enduring Good Deeds" (1).
10 - That they are expiation for sins: They remove them completely and shake them off as a tree shakes off its leaves, as was confirmed from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that he took a branch and shook it but it did not shake [leaves] off, then shook it and it did not shake [leaves] off [then shook it and it shook leaves off], so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar shake off sins as a tree shakes off its leaves" (2).
And in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no one on earth who says: La ilaha illa Allah, Allahu Akbar, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah except that his sins are expiated from him, even if they were like the foam of the sea" (3). Ibn Abi Al-Dunya and Al-Hakim added "Subhan Allah and Al-Hamdu Lillah" (4).
11 - That they move their sayer away from the Fire.
This was authentic in the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Every human from the children of Adam was created with three hundred and sixty joints. So whoever magnifies Allah (Takbir), praises Allah (Tahmid), declares Allah's Oneness (Tahlil), glorifies Allah (Tasbih), asks forgiveness from Allah (Istighfar), removes a stone from the path of Muslims, or a thorn or a bone from the path of Muslims, and enjoins good or forbids evil, according to the number of those three hundred and sixty (Sulama/joints); he indeed walks on that day having moved himself away from the Fire" (5).

12 - That they are charity for the one who does not find charity.
This was confirmed in the Hadith of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him: That some people from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: O Messenger of Allah, the wealthy people (Ahl al-Duthur) have gone with the rewards; they pray as we pray, they fast as we fast, and they give charity from the surplus of their wealth. He said: "Has not Allah made for you what you can give in charity? Indeed, in every Tasbihah is a charity, every Takbirah is a charity, every Tahmidah is a charity, every enjoining of good is a charity, every forbidding of evil is a charity, and in the sexual act (Bud') of one of you is a charity." They said: O Messenger of Allah, does one of us fulfill his desire and have a reward in it? He said: "Do you see if he placed it in the forbidden, would there be a burden upon him? Likewise, if he places it in the lawful, he has a reward" (1).
His saying: Al-Duthur - with Damma on Dal - plural of Dathr with Fatha: which is abundant wealth. And Al-Bud' - with Damma on Ba - is intercourse, and it was said: the private part itself.
- It was also confirmed from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that the Enduring Good Deeds are among the doors of charity. In the Hadith of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Upon every soul every day the sun rises is a charity from him upon himself from the doors of charity: Takbir, Subhan Allah, Al-Hamdu Lillah, La ilaha illa Allah, and Astaghfirullah, and he enjoins good and forbids evil, and removes the thorn from the path of people and the bone and the stone, and you guide the blind, and make the deaf and dumb hear until he understands, and guide the seeker to his need whose place you know, and run with the strength of your legs to the sorrowful seeking help, and lift with the strength of your arms with the weak. All that is from the doors of charity from you upon yourself.." (2).
13 - The gates of Heaven open for them.
As in the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: While we were praying with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, a man from the people said: Allahu Akbar Kabira, wa Al-Hamdu Lillahi Kathira, wa Subhan Allahi Bukratan wa Asila. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Who is the sayer of such and such? A man from the people said: I am, O Messenger of Allah. He said: "I wondered at it, the gates of Heaven were opened for it." Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: "I have not left them since I heard them from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him" (3).

Requirement Two: On the places where the Enduring Good Deeds are said
There are places for the Enduring Good Deeds to be said which are established in the noble Prophetic Sunnah. Among these places:
1 - If he wakes up at night.
It was confirmed that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to start with the Enduring Good Deeds or some of them when he woke up at night. Among that: He used to say Takbir ten times, Tahmid ten times, Tasbih ten times, Istighfar, and Tahlil ten times. From Shuraiq Al-Hawzani said: I entered upon Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, and asked her with what did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, start if he woke up at night. She said: "You asked me about something no one asked me about before you. When he woke up at night, he would say Allahu Akbar ten times, Al-Hamdu Lillah ten times, and say Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi ten times, and say Subhan Al-Malik Al-Quddus ten times, and ask forgiveness ten times, and say La ilaha illa Allah ten times, then say: Allahumma inni a'udhu bika min diq al-dunya wa diq yawm al-qiyamah (O Allah I seek refuge in You from the distress of the world and the distress of the Day of Resurrection) ten times, then he would start the prayer" (1).
2 - If he started the Prayer.
It was authenticated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he used to say at the start of prayer: Allahu Akbar Kabira, wa Al-Hamdu Lillahi Kathira, wa Subhan Allahi Bukratan wa Asila and repeat it. As in the Hadith of Jubayr bin Mut'im who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when he entered into prayer say: "Allahu Akbar Kabira, Allahu Akbar Kabira, wa Al-Hamdu Lillahi Kathira, Al-Hamdu Lillahi Kathira, Subhan Allahi Bukratan wa Asila, three times, I seek refuge in You from the accursed Satan from his spurring, blowing, and spitting" (2).

3 - In Salat Al-Tasabih (Prayer of Glorifications):
From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib: "O Abbas, O my uncle, shall I not give you? Shall I not grant you? Shall I not inform you? Shall I not do for you ten traits? If you do that, Allah will forgive you your sin, the first and the last of it, the old and the new of it, the mistake and the deliberate of it, the small and the big of it, the secret and the open of it? Ten traits: You pray four Rak'ahs reading in every Rak'ah Fatihat al-Kitab and a Surah. When you finish the reading in the first Rak'ah while you are standing, you say Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar fifteen times. Then you bow and say it while you are bowing ten times. Then you raise your head from bowing and say it ten times. Then you go down prostrating and say it while you are prostrating ten times. Then you raise your head from prostration and say it ten times. Then you prostrate and say it ten times. Then you raise your head and say it ten times. That is seventy-five in every Rak'ah. You do that in four Rak'ahs. If you can pray it once every day, then do so. If you do not do so, then once every Friday. If you do not do so, then once every month. If you do not do so, then once every year. If you do not do so, then once in your lifetime" (1).
4 - At the ends of the prescribed Prayers:
It was reported in several descriptions and manners, including:
a) First Description: You glorify (Tasbih) after every prayer thirty-three times, praise (Tahmid) thirty-three times, and magnify (Takbir) thirty-three times, and say to complete the hundred: La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah lahu al-mulk wa lahu al-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir. Due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever glorifies Allah after every prayer thirty-three times, and praises Allah thirty-three times, and magnifies Allah thirty-three times, and says to complete the hundred La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah lahu al-mulk wa lahu al-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, his sins are forgiven even if they were like the foam of the sea" (2).
b) Second Description: He glorifies thirty-three times, praises thirty-three times, and magnifies thirty-four times. Due to what was authenticated from Ka'b bin Ujrah, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet]: "Followers (Mu'aqqibat), the one who says them or does them after every prescribed prayer will not be disappointed: thirty-three Tasbihah, thirty-three Tahmidah, and thirty-four Takbirah" (3).
c) Third Description: Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar one hundred times.

6 - At the knot of Distress:
Due to what was confirmed from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say at distress: "La ilaha illa Allah Al-Halim Al-Karim, wa Subhan Allah Rabb Al-Arsh Al-Azim, wa Subhan Allah Rabb Al-Samawat Al-Sab' wa Rabb Al-Arsh Al-Azim" (3).
7 - When he retires to his bed:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Whoever says when he retires to his bed: "La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah lahu al-mulk wa lahu al-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir wa La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah, wa Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar; his sins - or he said his errors - are untied [forgiven] even if they were like the foam of the sea" (4).
8 - When taking to beds and preparing for sleep:
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, advised Ali and Fatima with that and said: "Shall I not guide you to something better than what you asked for? When you take to your beds, magnify Allah thirty-four times, praise thirty-three times, and glorify thirty-three times, for that is better for you than a servant" (5).
9 - Whoever wakes up at night (Ta'arra):
As in the Hadith of Ubada bin Al-Samit said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever wakes up at night and says when he wakes up La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahu al-mulk wa lahu al-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, Subhan Allah wa Al-Hamdu Lillah wa La ilaha illa Allah wa Allahu Akbar wa La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah, then supplicated Rabb Ighfir li (Lord forgive me) - or he said supplicated - it will be answered for him. If he got up and performed ablution then prayed, his prayer will be accepted" (6).

Requirement One: On explaining the virtue of Tasbih
In this requirement, we talk about Tasbih through the following two branches:
- Branch One: On the virtue of Tasbih:
The Hadiths reported regarding the virtue of Tasbih are either absolute (general), or restricted by a Name of Allah or an attribute or a number. We will begin by mentioning what was reported of absolute virtue for Tasbih, followed by what was reported restricted through the following:
a) What was reported regarding the virtue of Absolute Tasbih:
1 - The greatness of the reward of its sayer:
- In the Hadith of Mus'ab bin Sa'd said: My father told me, he said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: "Is one of you unable to earn a thousand good deeds every day?" A questioner from those sitting with him asked: How can one of us earn a thousand good deeds? He said: "He glorifies (Yusabbihu) a hundred times, so a thousand good deeds are written for him, or a thousand sins are removed from him" (1).
- And in the Hadith of Umm Hani - previous - that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to her: "Glorify Allah a hundred times, for it equates for you a hundred slaves you free from the offspring of Ishmael..." (2).
2 - That it is a charity among charities:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Dharr - previous - and in it: "Indeed, in every Tasbihah is a charity..." (3).
3 - That it fills what is between the heaven and the earth:
Due to what was authenticated in the Hadith of Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "... And Subhan Allah and Al-Hamdu Lillah fill - or fills - what is between the heaven and the earth..." (4).
b) What was reported regarding the virtue of Restricted Tasbih (by a Name or Attribute of Allah or a number):
1 - That it is heavy in the Balance, beloved to the Most Merciful:
As in the Sahih from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Two words, light on the tongue, heavy in the Balance, beloved to the Most Merciful: Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi, Subhan Allah Al-Azim" (5).
2 - That it is the most beloved speech to Allah:
Due to what is in Sahih Muslim from the Hadith of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Shall I not inform you of the most beloved speech to Allah?" I said: O Messenger of Allah: Inform me of the most beloved speech to Allah? He said: "Indeed, the most beloved speech to Allah is; Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi" (6).
3 - That it is the best speech and thus Allah chose it for His servants:
In Sahih Muslim that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked: Which speech is best? He said: "What Allah chose for His angels or His servants, Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi" (7).
4 - That it is the plants of Paradise:
As in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever says: Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi; a palm tree is planted for him in Paradise" (8). And in a narration from him said: "Subhan Allah Al-Azim wa Bi-Hamdihi; a tree is planted for him in Paradise" (9).

5 - That Tasbih is a cause of provision:
As in the Hadith of Sulayman bin Yasar from a man of the Ansar that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Noah said to his son: I command you with a commandment and I shorten it so you do not forget it; I command you with two things and forbid you from two things: As for the two I command you with, Allah and His righteous creation rejoice in them, and they increase access to Allah - and he mentioned one of them - and I command you with Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi; for they are the prayer of creation, and by them creation is provided for, [And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Allah] by His praise, but you do not understand their [way of] exalting. Indeed, He is ever Forbearing and Forgiving] (1) (2).
6 - That it stands in place of mother acts of worship like Night Prayer, Spending, and Jihad in the case of voluntary action:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Umama, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever is terrified of the night to endure it, or stingy with wealth to spend it, or cowardly of the enemy to fight him, let him increase in Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi; for it is more beloved to Allah than a mountain of gold spent in the path of Allah Almighty" (3).
7 - That it is a cause for forgiveness of sins and errors:
As in the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And whoever says Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi in a day a hundred times, his sins are forgiven even if they were like the foam of the sea" (4). And in a narration: "Whoever says Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi, Allah removes his sins from him even if they were more than the foam of the sea" (5).

8 - Doubling the reward for its sayer:
That was confirmed in the Hadith of Juwayriyah, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, left from her presence then returned after the sun had risen high while she was sitting. He said: "Are you still in the state I left you upon?" She said: Yes. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I have said after you four words three times, if they were weighed against what you said since today they would outweigh them: Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi number of His creation, satisfaction of Himself, weight of His Throne, and ink of His words (1)".
9 - That it is the gatherer of Dhikr.
Due to the Hadith of Abu Umama, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, saw me moving my lips, so he said to me: With what are you moving your lips, O Abu Umama? I said: I remember Allah, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "Shall I not inform you of what is more and better than your remembrance by night and day?" I said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: "You say: Subhan Allah the number of what He created, Subhan Allah the fill of what He created, Subhan Allah the number of what is in the earth, Subhan Allah the number of what His Book enumerated, Subhan Allah the fill of what His Book enumerated, Subhan Allah the number of everything, Subhan Allah the fill of everything..." (2).
Branch Two: On the places of Tasbih:
Tasbih was reported in the purified Sunnah in several places, including:
1 - At rejoicing for the victory of Religion:
Due to what was confirmed from the Mother of Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: "He used to increase in saying at the end of his affair: Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi, Astaghfirullah wa Atubu Ilayh. [Aisha said]: So I said: O Messenger of Allah, why do I see you increasing in saying Subhan Allah wa Bi-Hamdihi Astaghfirullah wa Atubu Ilayh. He said: My Lord informed me that I will see a sign in my Ummah, and commanded me - when I see that sign - to glorify His praise and ask His forgiveness, and I have seen it [When the victory of Allah has come and the conquest (1) And you see the people entering into the religion of Allah in multitudes (2) Then exalt [Him] with praise of your Lord and ask forgiveness of Him. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance (3)]" (3).

2 - Upon concluding a gathering of idle talk: Several Hadiths have been reported regarding this, the most complete being the Hadith of Jubayr bin Mut'im from his father in marfu' form: "Whoever says 'Subhanallahi wa bihamdihi, subhanaka Allahumma wa bihamdika ashhadu an la ilaha illa anta astaghfiruka wa atubu ilayka' (Glory be to Allah and His is the praise, Glory be to You O Allah and Your is the praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You); if he says it in a gathering of Dhikr (remembrance of Allah), it will be like a seal stamped upon it, and whoever says it in a gathering of idle talk, it will be an expiation for him" (1). Also among what has been reported upon concluding a gathering:
- The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever sits in a gathering and indulges in much idle talk in it and says before he rises from that gathering of his: 'Subhanaka Allahumma wa bihamdika ashhadu an la ilaha illa anta astaghfiruka wa atubu ilayk' (Glory be to You O Allah and Your is the praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You), except that Allah forgives him for what occurred in that gathering of his" (2).

3 - Upon astonishment at something: Due to the Hadith of Dhakwan from a man from the Ansar who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) visited a man who had a wound. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Call for him the physician of such and such tribe." He said: So they called him and he came and said: O Messenger of Allah, does medicine avail anything? He said: "Subhanallah (Glory be to Allah), has Allah sent down any disease on earth except that He has made a cure for it" (3).
- And for the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) on one of the paths of Medina while I was Junub (in a state of major ritual impurity), so I slipped away and went and bathed then came back. He said: "Where were you, O Abu Hurairah?" He said: I said: I was Junub and I disliked sitting with you without purification. He said: "Subhanallah (Glory be to Allah), indeed the believer does not become impure" (4).

4 - Before sunrise and before sunset:
- As in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says in the morning and in the evening 'Subhanallahil-Azim wa bihamdihi' (Glory be to Allah the Great and His is the praise) one hundred times, no one will come on the Day of Resurrection with anything better than what he brought, except one who said the like of what he said or increased upon it" (5).
- And the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says: 'Subhanallah' (Glory be to Allah) one hundred times before sunrise and before sunset, it is better than one hundred camels..." (6).

And due to what is established from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says in the morning 'Subhanallahi wa bihamdihi' (Glory be to Allah and His is the praise) one hundred times and in the evening one hundred times, his sins will be forgiven even if they were more than the foam of the sea" (1).

5 - In bowing (Ruku') and prostration (Sujud): As in Sahih Muslim from the Hadith of the Mother of the Believers Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to frequently say in his bowing and prostration: 'Subhanaka Allahumma Rabbana wa bihamdika Allahumma aghfir li' (Glory be to You O Allah our Lord and Your is the praise, O Allah forgive me), interpreting the Quran" (2). The meaning as Al-Nawawi said: "Meaning he does what he was commanded to do in it, i.e., from the saying of Allah Almighty {Then exalt [Him] with praise of your Lord and ask forgiveness of Him. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance}" (3). As in the long Hadith of Hudhayfah describing the night prayer of the Prophet (peace be upon him), he said: "Then he bowed saying: 'Subhana Rabbiyal-Azim' (Glory be to my Lord the Great) then he prostrated and said: 'Subhana Rabbiyal-A'la' (Glory be to my Lord the Most High)..." (4). And it is authentically reported from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "Subhana Rabbiyal-Azim wa bihamdihi" (5). And it is also authentically reported from him: "Subbuhun Quddusun Rabbul-Mala'ikati war-Ruh" (Glorified, Holy, Lord of the Angels and the Spirit) (6). The Muhaddith Al-Albani - may Allah have mercy on him - has cited the evidences for these Adhkar in 'The Description of the Prophet's Prayer', so refer to it.

6 - For one who notices something in his prayer: Due to what is in the Musnad from the Hadith of Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) led us in the Zuhr or Asr prayer, so he stood up (after two rak'ahs instead of sitting) and we said: Subhanallah, and he gestured with his hand meaning stand up. So we stood up, and when he finished his prayer he prostrated two prostrations then said: "If one of you remembers before he stands up fully straight, let him sit, and if he stands up fully straight, let him not sit" (7). And due to what is in it also from the Hadith of Sahl from Sa'd from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever notices something in his prayer, let him say: Subhanallah; for clapping is for women and Tasbih is for men" (8).

The Second Requirement: Clarifying the Virtue of Tahmid (Praising Allah)
We will talk, with the help of Allah Almighty, about Tahmid through the following two branches:

Branch One: On the Virtue of Tahmid:
Hadiths have been reported regarding the virtue of Tahmid, some of which are absolute and some are restricted by a description or number. We will begin by mentioning what has been reported regarding absolute Tahmid followed by what is restricted, through the following:

A) What has been reported regarding the virtue of absolute Tahmid:

1 - That it is the best type of gratitude: As in the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: "The best Dhikr is La ilaha illa Allah (There is no god but Allah) and the best gratitude is Alhamdu lillah (Praise be to Allah)" (1).

2 - Tahmid was the first thing Adam (peace be upon him) uttered after the soul was breathed into him: Due to what is established in the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) in marfu' form: "When the soul was breathed into Adam, and the soul reached his head, he sneezed and said: Alhamdu lillahi Rabbil-Alamin (Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds). So He, Blessed and Exalted, said to him: Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy on you)" (2).

3 - That it is the best supplication (Du'a): As in the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "The best Dhikr is La ilaha illa Allah, and the best Du'a is Alhamdu lillah" (3).

4 - That it is the most beloved thing to Allah: As in the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Deliberation is from Allah, and haste is from Satan. And no one accepts excuses more than Allah, and nothing is more beloved to Allah than praise (Al-Hamd)" (1).

B) What has been reported regarding the virtue of Tahmid restricted by a description or number:

1 - That it is a cause for attaining Allah's mercy: This is established from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id in marfu' form: "If the servant says 'Alhamdu lillah' often, Allah Almighty says: Write for My servant My mercy often" (2).

2 - That it fills the servant's scale on the Day of Resurrection: As in the Hadith of Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "...and Alhamdu lillah fills the Scale..." (3).

3 - Greatness of the reward: Many Hadiths have been reported regarding the reward of Hamd which clarify the greatness of the reward for its sayer. These Hadiths are:
a) The Hadith of Mus'ab bin Sa'd from his father (may Allah be pleased with him), that a Bedouin said to the Prophet (peace be upon him): Teach me a supplication perhaps Allah will benefit me with it. "He said: Say: Allahumma laka al-hamdu kulluhu wa ilayka yarji'u al-amru kulluhu (O Allah, to You belongs all praise and to You returns all matters)" (4).

b) The Hadith of Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Shall I not inform you of something, if you say it, then you strive night and day you will not reach it? I said: Yes. He said: Say: Alhamdu lillahi 'adada ma ahsa kitabuh, wal-hamdu lillahi 'adada ma fi kitabih, wal-hamdu lillahi 'adada ma ahsa khalquh, wal-hamdu lillahi mil'a ma fi khalqih, wal-hamdu lillahi mil'a samawatihi wa ardih, wal-hamdu lillahi 'adada kulli shay', wal-hamdu lillahi 'ala kulli shay'... (Praise be to Allah the number of what His Book has counted, and praise be to Allah the number of what is in His Book, and praise be to Allah the number of what His creation has counted, and praise be to Allah filling what is in His creation, and praise be to Allah filling His heavens and His earth, and praise be to Allah the number of everything, and praise be to Allah upon everything...)" (1).
- And in a narration: "Shall I not guide you to what is more than your remembrance of Allah night and day? Say: 'Alhamdu lillahi 'adada ma khalaq, wal-hamdu lillahi mil'a ma khalaq, wal-hamdu lillahi 'adada ma fi as-samawati wa ma fi al-ard, wal-hamdu lillahi 'adada ma ahsa kitabuh, wal-hamdu lillahi 'ala ma ahsa kitabuh, wal-hamdu lillahi 'adada kulli shay', wal-hamdu lillahi mil'a kulli shay'... (Praise be to Allah the number of what He created, and praise be to Allah filling what He created, and praise be to Allah the number of what is in the heavens and what is in the earth, and praise be to Allah the number of what His Book has counted, and praise be to Allah upon what His Book has counted, and praise be to Allah the number of everything, and praise be to Allah filling everything...)" (2).
d) The Hadith of Umm Hani (may Allah be pleased with her) and in it that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said to her: "...and praise Allah one hundred times; for it is equivalent for you to one hundred saddled and bridled horses that you carry [fighters] on in the way of Allah..." (3).

Branch Two: On the Places of Tahmid:
Many Hadiths have been reported regarding Tahmid in several places, including:

1 - When something pleasing appears: Due to what is in Al-Bukhari from the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "A Jewish boy used to serve the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he fell ill, so the Prophet (peace be upon him) came to visit him. He sat by his head and said to him: Embrace Islam. He looked at his father who was with him, so he said to him: Obey Abu Al-Qasim (peace be upon him). So he embraced Islam. The Prophet (peace be upon him) went out saying: Praise be to Allah who saved him from the Fire" (4).

2 - Upon sneezing: As in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "If one of you sneezes, let him say 'Alhamdu lillah' (Praise be to Allah), and let his brother or companion say to him 'Yarhamukallah' (May Allah have mercy on you). If he says to him 'Yarhamukallah', let him say 'Yahdikumullahu wa yuslihu balakum' (May Allah guide you and set your affairs right)" (1). And in a wording by Al-Tabarani: "Yaghfirullahu lana wa lakum" (May Allah forgive us and you) (2).

3 - Upon waking up from sleep: Due to the Hadith of Hudhayfah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When the Prophet (peace be upon him) went to his bed at night, he would place his hand under his cheek and then say: 'Allahumma bismika amutu wa ahya' (O Allah, in Your name I die and live), and when he woke up he said: 'Alhamdu lillahilladhi ahyana ba'da ma amatana wa ilayhin-nashur' (Praise be to Allah who gave us life after He caused us to die and to Him is the resurrection)" (3). And in a narration: "If one of you wakes up, let him say: 'Alhamdu lillahilladhi 'afani fi jasadi wa radda 'alayya ruhi wa adhina li bidhikrih' (Praise be to Allah who healed me in my body, returned my soul to me, and permitted me to remember Him)" (4).

4 - When starting the prayer: Starting the prayer with Hamd has been established in several manners:
a) The first manner: From Anas that a man came and entered the row while out of breath, so he said: "Alhamdu lillahi hamdan kathiran tayyiban mubarakan fih" (Praise be to Allah, much good and blessed praise). When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) finished his prayer, he said: "Which of you is the speaker of the words?" The people remained silent. He said: "Which of you is the speaker of them? For he did not say anything wrong." A man said: I came and was out of breath so I said them. He said: "I saw twelve angels rushing to see which of them would lift it" (5). The meaning as Al-Nawawi said regarding "hafazahun-nafas" (out of breath): "Meaning his breath pressed him due to his speed to catch the prayer. And 'fa-arramal-qawm' means they were silent" (6).

The second manner: From Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: When the Prophet (peace be upon him) rose at night to perform Tahajjud he would say: "Allahumma lakal-hamd, anta nurus-samawati wal-ardi wa man fihinn, wa lakal-hamd anta qayyimus-samawati wal-ardi wa man fihinn, wa lakal-hamd anta malikus-samawati wal-ardi wa man fihinn, wa lakal-hamd antal-haqq, wa wa'duka haqq, wa qawluka haqq, wa liqa'uka haqq, wal-jannatu haqq, wan-naru haqq, was-sa'atu haqq, wan-nabiyyuna haqq, wa Muhammadun haqq..." (O Allah, to You belongs praise, You are the Light of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs praise, You are the Sustainer of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs praise, You are the King of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs praise, You are the Truth, Your promise is true, Your word is true, the meeting with You is true, Paradise is true, the Fire is true, the Hour is true, the Prophets are true, and Muhammad is true...) (1).

5 - Upon starting recitation: Due to what is authentic from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) "that the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) used to start the prayer with Alhamdu lillahi Rabbil-Alamin" (2).

6 - Upon mounting a riding beast: Due to what is established from the Hadith of Ali bin Rabi'ah "that he was riding behind Ali (may Allah be pleased with him). When he placed his foot in the stirrup he said: Bismillah. When he settled on the back of the beast he said: Alhamdu lillah (three times), Allahu Akbar (three times), Subhanalladhi sakhkhara lana hadha wa ma kunna lahu muqrinin (Glory be to Him who has subjected this to us, and we could not have otherwise subdued it). Then he said: La ilaha illa anta subhanaka inni qad zalamtu nafsi faghfir li dhunubi; innahu la yaghfirudh-dhunuba illa ant (There is no god but You, Glory be to You, I have wronged myself so forgive me my sins; for indeed no one forgives sins except You). Then he leaned to one side and laughed. I said: O Commander of the Faithful, what makes you laugh? He said: I was riding behind the Prophet (peace be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did as I did, then I asked him as you asked me. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Indeed Allah wonders at the servant when he says: La ilaha illa anta inni qad zalamtu nafsi, faghfir li dhunubi innahu la yaghfirudh-dhunuba illa ant. He said: My servant knew that he has a Lord who forgives and punishes" (3).

7 - Upon astonishment at something: Due to what is established in Al-Bukhari from the Hadith of the Mother of the Believers Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "Praise be to Allah whose hearing encompasses all voices. Allah Almighty revealed to the Prophet (peace be upon him) [Certainly has Allah heard the speech of the one who argues with you concerning her husband]" (1).

8 - Upon sleeping and going to bed: Due to the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to say when he went to his bed: "Alhamdu lillahilladhi at'amana wa saqana wa kafana wa awana fakam mimman la kafiya lahu wa la mu'wi" (Praise be to Allah who fed us, gave us drink, sufficed us and sheltered us, for how many are there who have no one to suffice them nor shelter them) (2). And in a narration: "Whoever says when he goes to his bed 'Alhamdu lillahilladhi kafani wa awani, alhamdu lillahilladhi at'amani wa saqani, alhamdu lillahilladhi manna 'alayya wa afdal, inni as'aluka bi'izzatika an tunjiyani minan-nar' (Praise be to Allah who sufficed me and sheltered me, praise be to Allah who fed me and gave me drink, praise be to Allah who favored me and bestowed grace, I ask You by Your Might to save me from the Fire), he has indeed praised Allah with all the praises of all creation" (3).

9 - Upon starting a speech: This is established in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) taught us the Tashahhud in prayer, and the Tashahhud in need: Innal-hamda lillah [nahmaduhu] wa nasta'inuhu wa nastaghfiruhu wa na'udhu billahi min shururi anfusina wa sayyi'ati a'malina, man yahdihillahu fala mudilla lah, wa man yudlil fala hadiya lah... (Indeed, all praise is due to Allah, [we praise Him] and seek His help and forgiveness, and we seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and our bad deeds. Whomever Allah guides, no one can misguide, and whomever He misguides, no one can guide...)" (4).

10 - When seeing what one loves or dislikes: Due to what is established from the Mother of the Believers Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "When the Prophet (peace be upon him) saw what he liked, he would say: 'Alhamdu lillahi alladhi bini'matihi tatimmus-salihat' (Praise be to Allah by Whose grace good deeds are completed). And when he saw what he disliked, he would say: 'Alhamdu lillahi 'ala kulli hal' (Praise be to Allah in every condition)" (5).
