text:
11 - When seeing an afflicted person: As in the Hadith of Ibn Umar: "Whoever sees an afflicted person and says: 'Alhamdu lillahilladhi 'afani mimma ibtalaka bihi wa faddalani 'ala kathirin mimman khalaqa tafdila' (Praise be to Allah who has spared me from what He has afflicted you with and preferred me greatly over many of those whom He has created), that affliction will not befall him" (1). And in a narration: "That was the gratitude for that blessing" (2).

12 - When eating or drinking or clearing the table, it is recommended to praise Allah: As in the Hadith of Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed Allah is pleased with the servant who eats a meal and praises Him for it, or drinks a drink and praises Him for it" (3). And due to what is established in the Hadith of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to say when he ate or drank: 'Alhamdu lillahilladhi at'ama wa saqa wa sawwaghahu, wa ja'ala lahu makhraja' (Praise be to Allah who fed and gave drink and made it easy to swallow, and made a way out for it)" (4). And in the Hadith of Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) that when the Prophet (peace be upon him) cleared his table he said: "Alhamdu lillahi kathiran tayyiban mubarakan fihi ghayra makfiyyin wa la muwadda'in wa la mustaghnan 'anhu Rabbuna" (Praise be to Allah, abundant, good, blessed praise. He is not insufficient, nor is He abandoned, nor is He dispensable, our Lord) (5). And due to what is in the Hadith of Mu'adh bin Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever eats food and says: 'Alhamdu lillahilladhi at'amani hadha wa razaqanihi min ghayri hawlin minni wa la quwwah' (Praise be to Allah who fed me this and provided me with it without any power or might from me), his past sins will be forgiven" (6). And in the Hadith of Abu Umamah also, he said: When he cleared his table he would say: "Alhamdu lillahi hamdan kathiran tayyiban mubarakan fih, alhamdu lillahilladhi kafana wa awana ghayra makfiyyin wa la makfurin wa la mustaghnan 'anhu Rabbuna" (Praise be to Allah, abundant, good, blessed praise. Praise be to Allah who sufficed us and sheltered us, He is not insufficient, nor is He denied, nor is He dispensable, our Lord) (7).

The Third Requirement: Clarifying the Virtue of the Statement of Tawhid
The discussion about the Statement of Tawhid will be through the following two branches:

Branch One: On the Virtue of the Statement of Tawhid:
The Statement of Tawhid is: "La ilaha illa Allah" (There is no god but Allah). Many Hadiths have been reported regarding its virtues from the best of creation (peace be upon him), including:

1 - That it is the greatest pillar of Islam: Due to the Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Islam is built on five [pillars]: Testifying that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establishing prayer, giving Zakat, Hajj, and fasting Ramadan" (1).

2 - The Protector and Preventer: As in the Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "I have been commanded to fight the people until they testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, and give Zakat. If they do that, their blood and wealth are protected from me except by the right of Islam, and their reckoning is with Allah" (2).

3 - The Savior from the Fire: As established in the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "He will come out of the Fire who said: La ilaha illa Allah and in his heart is the weight of a barley grain of good. And he will come out of the Fire who said: La ilaha illa Allah and in his heart is the weight of a wheat grain of good. And he will come out of the Fire who said: La ilaha illa Allah and in his heart is the weight of an atom of good" (3).

They said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: Testifying that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establishing prayer, giving Zakat, fasting Ramadan..." (1).
- And in the Hadith of Mu'adh when the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent him to Yemen, he said: "When you come to them, invite them to testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah..." (2).

5 - Whoever says it will be the happiest of people with the intercession of the Prophet (peace be upon him): Due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: It was said, O Messenger of Allah, who will be the happiest of people with your intercession on the Day of Resurrection? The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "I thought, O Abu Hurairah, that no one would ask me about this Hadith before you because of what I saw of your eagerness for Hadith. The happiest of people with my intercession on the Day of Resurrection is the one who says: La ilaha illa Allah purely from his heart..." (3).

6 - It inherits Paradise and forbids entry into Hellfire: As in the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) had Mu'adh riding behind him on the saddle. He said: O Mu'adh bin Jabal. He said: At your service, O Messenger of Allah, and at your pleasure. He said: O Mu'adh. He said: At your service, O Messenger of Allah, and at your pleasure (three times). He said: "There is no one who testifies that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah truthfully from his heart except that Allah prohibits him from the Fire. He said: O Messenger of Allah, shall I not inform the people so they rejoice? He said: Then they would rely on it. And Mu'adh informed of it at his death to avoid sin" (4).
- And in the Hadith of Itban bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him), the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "...For Allah has forbidden from the Fire the one who says La ilaha illa Allah seeking thereby the Face of Allah" (5).

- And in the Hadith of Ubadah bin As-Samit (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "He said: Whoever testifies that there is no god but Allah alone with no partner and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, and that Jesus is the servant of Allah and His messenger and His word which He bestowed on Mary and a spirit from Him, and that Paradise is true and Hell is true, Allah will admit him into Paradise according to what he has done of deeds" (2).

7 - The doors of heaven are opened for it until it reaches the Throne: Due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "No servant has ever said La ilaha illa Allah sincerely except that the doors of heaven are opened for it until it reaches the Throne, as long as he avoids major sins" (3).

8 - That it is the best Dhikr: As in the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "The best Dhikr is La ilaha illa Allah and the best Du'a is Alhamdu lillah" (4).

9 - The Beneficial Gatherer: Due to what is established in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says La ilaha illa Allah, it will benefit him one day of his time, afflicted before that by whatever afflicts him" (5).

10 - The Erasing Good Deed: As in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever comes with the good deed" he said: Whoever comes with La ilaha illa Allah, "and whoever comes with the evil deed" he said: Whoever comes with Shirk (6).

11 - Outweighing the Heavens and the Earth: This is established from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Shall I not tell you of Noah's advice to his son? They said: Yes. He said: Noah advised his son and said to his son: O my son, I advise you with two things and forbid you from two things. I advise you with the statement: La ilaha illa Allah; for if it were placed in one scale pan, and the heavens and the earth were placed in a scale pan, it would outweigh them. And if they were a ring, it would break them until it reached Allah..." (2).
- And from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed Allah will distinguish a man from my community before all of creation on the Day of Resurrection. Ninety-nine scrolls will be laid out for him, each scroll being as far as the eye can see, then He will say: 'Do you deny any of this? Have those who wrote it, My guardians, oppressed you?' He will say: 'No, my Lord.' He will say: 'Do you have an excuse?' He will say: 'No, my Lord.' Allah Almighty will say: 'Yes, you have a good deed with Us, for there is no oppression upon you today.' Then a card will be brought out containing: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah, wa ashhadu anna Muhammadan abduhu wa rasulug. He will say: 'Bring your weight.' He will say: 'O Lord, what is this card compared to these scrolls?' It will be said: 'Indeed you will not be oppressed.' The scrolls will be put in one pan and the card in the other. The scrolls will be light, and the card will be heavy, for nothing is heavy with the Name of Allah" (3).

12 - Freer of Necks (Slaves): As in the Hadith of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir (There is no god but Allah alone with no partner, His is the dominion and His is the praise and He is over all things competent) ten times, it is as if he freed four souls from the children of Ishmael" (4).

13 - The best of what the Prophets said: This is established from the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather; that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The best supplication is the supplication on the Day of Arafah, and the best of what I and the prophets before me have said is: La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir" (2).

14 - Filling what is between heaven and earth: This is authentic in the Hadith of Umm Hani (may Allah be pleased with her), the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "...and say La ilaha illa Allah one hundred times - Ibn Khalaf said: I think he said: it fills what is between heaven and earth" (3).

15 - Great reward: For the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir two hundred times in a day, no one before him will surpass him, and no one after him will reach him except one who did better than his deed" (4).

16 - The best and highest branch of Faith: This is established in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Faith has sixty-odd branches, the best of them is the saying La ilaha illa Allah, and the lowest of them is removing a harmful object from the road, and modesty is a branch of faith" (5).

Branch Two: On the Places where the Statement of Tawhid is Said:
There are many places where the Statement of Tawhid is said, as established in the purified Sunnah. Among these places:

1 - Following the obligatory prayers:
- The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to say following every obligatory prayer: "La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, Allahumma la mani'a lima a'tayt wa la mu'tiya lima mana't wa la yanfa'u dhal-jaddi minkal-jadd" (There is no god but Allah alone with no partner, His is the dominion and His is the praise and He is over all things competent. O Allah, there is no preventer of what You have given, and no giver of what You have prevented, and richness does not benefit the rich against You) (1). And in a narration: He used to say following every obligatory prayer and when he said Salam: "La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd yuhyi wa yumit wa huwa hayyun la yamut biyadihil-khayr wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir - three times - Allahumma la mani'a lima a'tayt wa la mu'tiya lima mana't wa la yanfa'u dhal-jaddi minkal-jadd".
- And in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr (may Allah be pleased with them); that he used to say following every prayer when he said Salam: "La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah, la ilaha illa Allah, wa la na'budu illa iyyah, lahun-ni'matu wa lahul-fadlu wa lahuth-thana'ul-hasan, la ilaha illa Allah mukhlisina lahud-dina wa law karihal-kafirun" (2).
- And in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever glorifies Allah following every prayer thirty-three times, and praises Allah thirty-three times, and magnifies Allah thirty-three times, and says to complete the hundred: La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, his sins will be forgiven even if they were like the foam of the sea" (3).
- And in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) in marfu' form, he said: "La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, after he prays Fajr ten times, Allah Almighty will write for him

3 - After the Tashahhud: It is authentic that the Prophet (peace be upon him) heard a man saying in his Tashahhud: "Allahumma inni as'aluka bi-anna lakal-hamd, la ilaha illa ant, wahdaka la sharika lak, al-mannan ya badi'as-samawati wal-ard, ya dhal-jalali wal-ikram, ya hayyu ya qayyum; inni as'alukal-jannata wa a'udhu bika minan-nar" (O Allah, I ask You by virtue of the fact that praise is due to You, there is no god but You, alone with no partner, the Bestower, O Originator of the heavens and the earth, O Possessor of Majesty and Honor, O Ever-Living, O Sustainer; I ask You for Paradise and seek refuge in You from the Fire). The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Do you know what he has supplicated Allah with?" They said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, he has supplicated Allah by His Greatest Name, which if He is called by it, He answers, and if He is asked by it, He gives" (3).

4 - In Istisqa' (Prayer for Rain): As in the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The people complained to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about the lack of rain, so he ordered a pulpit and it was placed for him in the prayer place, and he promised the people a day they should go out. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out when the rim of the sun appeared, sat on the pulpit, magnified Allah and praised Allah Almighty. Among what he said in his sermon was: "La ilaha illa Allah yaf'alu ma yurid, Allahumma anta Allahu la ilaha illa ant, antal-ghaniyyu wa nahnul-fuqara'u anzil 'alaynal-ghaytha, waj'al ma anzalta lana quwwatan wa balaghan ila hin..." (There is no god but Allah, He does what He wills. O Allah, You are Allah, there is no god but You, You are the Rich and we are the poor, send down rain upon us, and make what You send down strength and sufficiency for us for a time...) (4).

9 - During panic: This is established in the Hadith of Zainab bint Jahsh (may Allah be pleased with her), that the Prophet (peace be upon him) entered upon her in a state of panic saying: "La ilaha illa Allah, woe to the Arabs from an evil that has approached. Today a hole has been opened in the barrier of Gog and Magog like this," and he made a circle with his thumb and the finger next to it. Zainab bint Jahsh said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, will we be destroyed while the righteous are among us? He said: "Yes, when wickedness prevails" (1).

10 - In Supplication: Due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to say: "La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu a'azza jundahu wa nasara 'abdahu wa ghalabal-ahzaba wahdahu, fala shay'a ba'dah" (There is no god but Allah alone, He honored His army, helped His servant, and defeated the confederates alone, so there is nothing after Him) (2).

11 - On the Day of Arafah: Due to what is established in the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather, that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The best supplication is the supplication on the Day of Arafah, and the best of what I and the prophets before me have said is: La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir" (3).

12 - In the Morning and Evening Adhkar: As established in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk, wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir' in a day one hundred times, it will be equivalent for him to freeing ten slaves, one hundred good deeds will be written for him, one hundred bad deeds will be erased from him, and it will be a protection for him from Satan on that day of his until evening. And no one brings anything better than what he brought except one who did more than that" (4).
- And the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala...

- And the Hadith of Abu Ayyub (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir' ten times, it is as if he freed four souls from the children of Ishmael" (2).
- And the Hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "...And whoever says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir', it is like freeing a soul" (3).
- And the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to say when evening came: "Amsayna wa amsal-mulku lillah, wal-hamdu lillah, la ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir..." (We have reached the evening and the dominion belongs to Allah, and praise be to Allah, there is no god but Allah alone with no partner, His is the dominion and His is the praise and He is over all things competent...) (4).
- And due to what is authentic from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): "Whoever says in the morning: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd yuhyi wa yumit wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir' ten times, Allah writes for him with each one he says ten good deeds, erases from him ten bad deeds, raises him by it ten degrees, they are for him like ten slaves, and they are for him a guard from the beginning of the day until its end, and no deed he does that day will overcome them; and if he says it in the evening it is the same" (5).

Abd al-Rahman entered upon me with a Siwak in his hand and I was supporting the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). I saw him looking at it...

...and I knew he loved the Siwak. I said: Shall I take it for you? He signaled with his head yes. So I took it and it was hard for him, so I said: Shall I soften it for you? He signaled with his head yes. So I softened it. There was a leather vessel - or a wooden vessel, Umar doubts - with water in front of him. And in a narration: "He whose last words are La ilaha illa Allah enters Paradise" (3). And in a narration: "Increase in the testimony that there is no god but Allah, before a barrier is put between you and it, and prompt it to your dying ones" (4).

And whoever says to his companion 'Come let me gamble with you', let him give charity" (6).

The Fourth Requirement: Clarifying the Virtue of Takbir
The discussion about Takbir will be through the following two branches:

Branch One: On the Virtue of Takbir:
Many Hadiths have been reported regarding the virtue of Takbir. We mentioned some of them when discussing the virtue of the enduring good deeds generally. These are some virtues reported mentioning Takbir specifically.

1 - The word of Fitrah (natural disposition): Due to the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Prophet (peace be upon him) would not raid except at dawn prayer. If he heard Adhan he would hold back, otherwise he would raid. He listened one day and heard a man saying: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. He said: Upon the Fitrah..." (1).

2 - Great reward: As in the Hadith of Umm Hani (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "...and say Allahu Akbar one hundred times; for it is equivalent for you to one hundred garlanded accepted camels..." (2).

Branch Two: On the Places where Takbir is Said
There are multiple places for Takbir established in the purified Prophetic Sunnah, including:

1 - Upon starting prayer: As in the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to start prayer with Takbir..." (3). And the Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "The key to prayer is purification, its prohibition (entering its sanctity) is the Takbir, and its permission (exiting it) is the Taslim" (4).

2 - Upon night prayer: Due to the Hadith of Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman (may Allah be pleased with him): "That he prayed with the Prophet (peace be upon him) [night prayer] and when he said Takbir, he said: Allahu Akbar [three times] Dhul-Malakuti wal-Jabaruti wal-Kibriya'i wal-Azamah (Possessor of Kingdom, Power, Greatness and Grandeur)..." (5).
- And the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) rose at night he would say Takbir, then say: "Subhanaka Allahumma wa bihamdika wa tabaraka ismuka wa ta'ala jadduka wa la ilaha ghayruk, then he says: La ilaha illa Allah; three times, then he says: Allahu Akbar kabira; three times A'udhu billahis-Sami'il-Alim minash-shaytanir-rajim min hamzihi wa nafkhihi wa nafthih..." (6).

3 - Upon rejoicing in victory: As in the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him): "That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) invaded Khaybar. We prayed the morning prayer there at dawn darkness. Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) mounted, and Abu Talha mounted and I was riding behind Abu Talha. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) rode quickly in the lane of Khaybar and my knee was touching the thigh of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Then he uncovered the Izar from his thigh until I was looking at the whiteness of the thigh of the Prophet (peace be upon him). When he entered the town he said: Allahu Akbar, Khaybar is destroyed. Indeed, when we descend in the open space of a people, evil is the morning of those who were warned..." (1).

4 - If one fears a formidable ruler: This is established in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: "If you come to a formidable ruler, fearing that he might attack you, say: Allahu Akbar, Allah is mightier than all His creation, Allah is mightier than what I fear and guard against. I seek refuge in Allah, there is no god but Him, who holds the seven heavens lest they fall upon the earth except by His permission, from the evil of your servant so-and-so, and his soldiers, followers, and partisans from among Jinn and men. O Allah be my protector from their evil. Exalted is Your praise, and mighty is Your protection, and blessed is Your name, and there is no god other than You; three times" (2).
And it is established in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him): If any of you has a leader whose arrogance or injustice he fears, let him say: "Allahumma Rabbas-samawatis-sab'i wa Rabbal-arshil-azim, kun li jaran min fulan bin fulan wa ahzabihi min khala'iqika, an yafruta 'alayya ahadun minhum, aw yatgha, 'azza jaruka wa jalla thana'uka, wa la ilaha illa ant" (O Allah, Lord of the seven heavens and Lord of the Mighty Throne, be a protector for me from so-and-so son of so-and-so and his parties from Your creation, lest any of them exceeds bounds against me or transgresses. Mighty is Your protection and exalted is Your praise, and there is no god but You) (3).

5 - Upon martyrdom: Due to the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Prophet (peace be upon him) sent some people from Banu Sulaym to Banu Amir, seventy in number. When they arrived, my maternal uncle said to them: I will go ahead of you, if they grant me safety until I convey to them from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), otherwise you will be close to me. So he went ahead and they granted him safety. While he was speaking to them about the Prophet (peace be upon him), they signaled to a man among them who stabbed him and pierced him through. He said: Allahu Akbar, I have won, by the Lord of the Kaaba. Then they turned upon the rest of his companions and killed them..." (1).

6 - Upon ascending and looking down upon a place: It is authentic in the Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) invaded Khaybar, or he said when the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) headed out, the people looked down upon a valley and raised their voices with Takbir: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, La ilaha illa Allah. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Be gentle with yourselves, for you are not calling upon one who is deaf or absent; indeed you are calling upon One who is Hearing, Near..." (2).

7 - Before sunrise and before sunset: As in the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "...and whoever says Allahu Akbar one hundred times before sunrise and before sunset, it is better than freeing one hundred slaves..." (3).

8 - At Al-Safa: Due to the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) went out to Al-Safa. When he came near Al-Safa he recited: [Indeed, as-Safa and al-Marwah are among the symbols of Allah. So whoever makes Hajj to the House or performs 'umrah - there is no blame upon him for walking between them...]. We begin with what Allah began with. So he began with Al-Safa and climbed upon it until he saw the House [Kaaba]. He faced the Qiblah, unified Allah, and magnified Him three times [Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar]..." (4).

9 - In the two Eids and the days of Tashriq: Takbir is established in the two Eids, and it is prescribed by consensus of the scholars. Among what has been reported regarding it:
- The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) that he used to say Takbir: "Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, La ilaha illa Allah, wallahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, wa lillahil-hamd" (1).
- And the Hadith of Ibn Masud (may Allah be pleased with them) that he used to say Takbir during the days of Tashriq: "Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, La ilaha illa Allah, wallahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, wa lillahil-hamd" (2).

10 - During Sa'y between Safa and Marwah: He (peace be upon him) used to say during Sa'y: "Rabbi ighfir warham wa tajawaz 'amma ta'lam... Allahu Akbar (three times) wa lillahil-hamd, Allahu Akbar 'ala ma hadana, wal-hamdu lillahi 'ala ma awlana..." (3).

11 - Upon mounting the back of a riding beast or vehicle: Due to what was reported in the Hadith of Ali bin Rabi'ah that he was riding behind Ali (may Allah be pleased with him), so when he placed his saddle in the stirrup he said: "Bismillah. When he settled on the back of the beast he said: Alhamdu lillah (three times) and Allahu Akbar (three times)..." (4).

12 - Upon receiving glad tidings of victory: As in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: "While the Prophet (peace be upon him) was in Medina, he suddenly said: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, the victory of Allah has come, and the opening has come, and the people of Yemen have come, a people with pure hearts and gentle obedience. Faith is Yemeni and Fiqh is Yemeni and Wisdom is Yemeni" (5).

13 - Upon sighting the crescent moon: This is established in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: "When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saw the crescent moon he would say: Allahu Akbar, Allahumma ahillahu 'alayna bil-amni wal-iman was-salamati wal-islam wat-tawfiqi lima tuhibbu wa tarda, Rabbuna wa Rabbukallah" (Allah is the Greatest, O Allah bring it over us with security and faith, safety and Islam, and success for what You love and are pleased with, our Lord and your Lord is Allah) (1).

14 - Upon seeing a sign: Due to the Hadith of Buraydah bin Al-Husayb (may Allah be pleased with him): That he was in Khurasan and visited a brother of his who was sick. He found him dying and saw sweat on his forehead. He said: Allahu Akbar, I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: "The believer dies with sweat on the brow" (2).

15 - Upon receiving glad tidings of a newborn: As in the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Abu Talha married Umm Sulaym - and he mentioned the Hadith at length - and in it Abu Talha said: O Messenger of Allah, Umm Sulaym has given birth. He said: Allahu Akbar, what did she give birth to? I said: A boy. He said: Alhamdu lillah..." (3).

16 - Upon seeing what one loves: This is established in the Hadith of Uqbah bin Suwayd Al-Ansari; that he heard his father, who was one of the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him), say: "We returned with the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) from the invasion of Khaybar. When Uhud appeared to him, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Allahu Akbar, a mountain that loves us and we love it" (4).

17 - Upon slaughtering: As in the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) sacrificed two horned rams of white and black color, he slaughtered them with his hand, mentioned Allah's name, said Takbir, and placed his foot on their sides" (5).

The Fifth Requirement: Clarifying the Virtue of Hawqala
Hawqala is: "La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (There is no change nor power except by Allah). We will talk about it through the following two branches:

Branch One: On the Virtue of Hawqala:
A number of Hadiths have been reported regarding the virtue of Hawqala from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), including:

1 - That it is a treasure from the treasures of Paradise:
- As in the Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Prophet (peace be upon him) heard me while I was saying 'La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah'. He said: O Abdullah bin Qays, shall I not guide you to a word from the treasures of Paradise? I said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (1).
- And in the Hadith of Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to me: "Shall I not guide you to a treasure from the treasures of Paradise? I said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (2).
- And the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to me: "Increase in saying 'La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah'; for it is [a treasure] from the treasures of Paradise" (3).

2. Sunan Ibn Majah (2/1256) under number (3825), and Al-Albani authenticated it in Sahih Al-Jami' under number (7820).
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (5/580), and Al-Albani authenticated it in Sahih Al-Targhib (2/248) under number (1580).

2 - That it is a word from under the Throne: Due to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Shall I not teach you, or shall I not guide you to a word from under the Throne from the treasures of Paradise? You say: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah, and Allah says: My servant has submitted and surrendered" (1).

3 - That it is a gate from the gates of Paradise: This was reported in the Hadith of Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Shall I not guide you to a gate from the gates of Paradise? He said: And what is it? He said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (2).
- And in the Hadith of Qays bin Sa'd bin Ubadah that his father handed him over to the Prophet (peace be upon him) to serve him. He said: The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) came to me while I had prayed two rak'ahs, so he nudged me with his foot and said: "Shall I not guide you to a gate from the gates of Paradise? I said: Yes. He said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (3).

4 - That it is the planting of Paradise: As in the Hadith of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him) "that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), on the night he was taken on the Night Journey, passed by Abraham (peace be upon him). He said: Who is with you O Gabriel? He said: This is Muhammad. Abraham (peace be upon him) said to him: O Muhammad, command your nation to increase in the planting of Paradise; for its soil is good and its land is vast. He said: What is the planting of Paradise? He said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (4).

And the Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Increase in the planting of Paradise; for its water is sweet and its soil is good, so increase in its planting. They said: O Messenger of Allah, what is its planting? He said: Ma sha'a Allah, la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (1).

5 - That it is one of the expiations for sins: Due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "There is no one on earth who says 'La ilaha illa Allah, wallahu akbar, wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah' except that his sins are expiated from him, even if they were like the foam of the sea" (2).

6 - That it is one of the saviors from the Fire: This is established in the Hadith of Al-Agharr Abu Muslim who said: "I testify about Abu Sa'id and Abu Hurairah that they testified about the Prophet (peace be upon him); that he said: Whoever says 'La ilaha illa Allah, wallahu akbar', his Lord affirms him and says: 'There is no god but Me and I am Greatest'. And when he says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu', He says: Allah says: 'There is no god but Me alone'. And when he says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah', Allah says: 'There is no god but Me alone, I have no partner'. And when he says: 'La ilaha illa Allah lahul-mulku wa lahul-hamd', Allah says: 'There is no god but Me, Mine is the dominion and Mine is the praise'. And when he says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah', He says: 'There is no god but Me and there is no change nor power except by Me'. And he used to say: Whoever says it in his illness then dies, the Fire will not taste him" (3).

2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (5/509), and Al-Albani graded it Hasan in Al-Ta'liq Al-Raghib (2/249).

7 - That it is one of the causes of forgiveness of sins: As in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever says 'La ilaha illa Allah wallahu akbar, la ilaha illa Allah wahdahu, la ilaha illa Allah wa la sharika lah, la ilaha illa Allah lahul-mulku wa lahul-hamd, la ilaha illa Allah wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah', counting them five with his fingers, then said whoever says them in a day or a night or in a month, then dies in that day or in that night, or in that month, his sin will be forgiven" (1).

Branch Two: On the Places where Hawqala is Said:
The mention of Hawqala has been reported in several places derived from what is authentic from the Prophet (peace be upon him), including:

1 - Following prayers: "He (peace be upon him) used to say following the prayer when he said Salam before he stood up, raising his voice with it: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd, wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah, la ilaha illa Allah, wa la na'budu illa iyyah, lahun-ni'matu wa lahul-fadlu, wa lahuth-thana'ul-hasan, la ilaha illa Allah mukhlisina lahud-dina, wa law karihal-kafirun'" (2).

2 - Upon rising for night prayer: This is established in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) when he rose for prayer in the middle of the night would say: "Allahumma lakal-hamd anta qayyimus-samawati wal-ardi wa man fihinn, wa lakal-hamd lakal-mulkus-samawati wal-ardi wa man fihinn, wa lakal-hamd anta nurus-samawati wal-ardi wa man fihinn, wa lakal-hamd anta malikus-samawati wal-ard, wa lakal-hamd antal-haqq, wa wa'duka haqq, wa liqa'uka haqq, wal-jannatu haqq, wan-naru haqq, wan-nabiyyuna haqq, wa Muhammadun sallallahu 'alayhi wa sallama haqq, was-sa'atu haqq, Allahumma laka aslamt, wa bika amant, wa 'alayka tawakkalt, wa ilayka anabt, wa bika khasamt, wa ilayka hakamta, faghfir li ma qaddamtu wa ma akhkhart, wa ma asrartu wa ma a'lant, wa ma anta a'lamu bihi minni, antal-muqaddimu wa antal-mu'akhkhir, anta ilahi, la ilaha illa anta wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" (3).

3 - Upon leaving the house: As in the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If a man leaves his house and says: 'Bismillah tawakkaltu 'alallah, wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah' (In the name of Allah, I rely on Allah, and there is no change nor power except by Allah), it is said to him: You are sufficed, guided, and protected, and Satan moves away from him" (1).

4 - Whoever wakes up at night: As in the Hadith of Ubadah bin As-Samit (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever wakes up at night and says: 'La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah, lahul-mulk wa lahul-hamd, wa huwa 'ala kulli shay'in qadir, alhamdu lillah wa subhanallah wa la ilaha illa Allah wallahu akbar wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah', then says: 'Allahumma aghfir li' (O Allah forgive me), or supplicates, he will be answered; if he performs Wudu and prays, his prayer will be accepted" (2).
